title: 113_s2364
content: S. 2364 is a bill introduced in the 113th Congress to amend chapter 111 of title 28, United States Code, regarding protective orders, sealing of cases, and disclosures of discovery information in civil actions. Introduced by Mr. Blumenthal, the bill was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary after being read twice. The "Sunshine in Litigation Act of 2014" aims to amend chapter 111 of title 28, US Code, regarding protective orders, sealing of cases, and disclosures of discovery information in civil actions. It imposes restrictions on protective orders, sealing of cases, and settlements. The "Sunshine in Litigation Act of 2014" amends Chapter 111 of Title 28, US Code by adding restrictions on protective orders, sealing of cases, and settlements in civil actions. It prohibits courts from entering orders that restrict the disclosure of information relevant to public health or safety without independent findings of fact. Additionally, a court shall not enforce any provision of a settlement agreement that prohibits parties from disclosing the fact that a settlement was reached or the terms of the settlement, except for the amount of money paid. The section also outlines exceptions for information classified under criteria established by an Executive order to be kept secret in the interest of national defense or foreign policy. The Executive order allows information to be kept secret for national defense or foreign policy interests, or if it reveals intelligence sources and methods. The amendments made by this Act regarding restrictions on protective orders and sealing of cases and settlements will take effect 30 days after enactment. They apply only to orders or agreements entered into after the effective date and do not allow for reconsideration, modification, or reversal of orders entered before the Act's effective date.
